captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

J.F. MUSIAL: We've been doing
these factory and workshop
tours for over a year now.

After hundreds of hours of
footage shot, I've come to

realize you can never assume
what you'll see
through the next door.

Now, this is the home of
X-raid, just outside of
Frankfurt, Germany.

And if it weren't for the big
service trucks parked outside,

you wouldn't expect this is the
home of one of the most

successful cross-country rally
teams in the world.

As a racing enthusiast and a
passionate photographer, I
don't think you can beat this.

Le Mans and Monaco have their
charm and their allure thanks

to the brilliant markers
behind the scene.

But this, cross-country
rally--

this is the perfect mix of man
and machine conquering the

most beautiful terrain you
didn't know existed.

As great as it looks, it's a
mere small percentage of what

these trucks actually
see over the course
of a two-week rally.

And ultimately, I want to see
what it looks like from inside
the cockpit.

But first, let's see how
these trucks get built.

This is the home of X-raid,
the 2013 Dakar winners.

Now, here's where you're going
to find Minis as well as BMW

X3s being fabricated for
cross-country rallies.

Now, they're not actually
Minis and X3s.

They're actually very heavily
modified tube-frame chassis
that look like Minis and X3s.

And they compete in
cross-country rallies.

So what is the difference
between a normal rally and a
cross-country rally?

Well, the name states
it very simply.

These are trucks meant to go
long distances on their own,

self-dependent, with supplies,
with gear, in probably the

worst and most rugged terrain
the world has ever seen.

There are several cross-country
rallies in the

world, including Abu Dhabi,
Morocco, Portugal, Poland.

The biggest of those,
of course, is Dakar.

That's really the motorsports
event that kicks off the year
in January.

It's a 14-day event where you
see these trucks going

anywhere between 500 to 800
kilometers in a day.

Some of them finish the
stages in 10 hours,
some of them 25 hours.

SVEN QUANDT: I met one person
who has done Dakar.

And he said, OK, you
didn't do this?

Are you interested
to go to Dakar?

I said, yes, it's
an adventure.

It's the biggest adventure
probably in
motorsports you can do.

And it's probably, beside,
let's say, Le Mans, the

biggest challenge you can
do in motorsports.

STEPHANE PETERHANSEL: I saw
this race in Africa.

And I saw in a movie, in
television, and I saw a very
nice landscape.

And I said, OK, I want to do
this race, because the

landscape are really
incredible.
And I want to do this race.

And when I start, when I did
my first race in Africa, it
was amazing for me.
I say, OK, this is my race.

I want to do this kind of race
because it's the best
competition.

NANI ROMA: It's one of the
last things maybe in
motorsport--

OK, you have a technology, but
exists the human side.

You need to fight by
yourself to come to
the end of the stage.

SVEN QUANDT: It's not like
in circuit racing.

You have to know in
cross-country racing, you race

against an enemy where you don't
know where he is the

whole day, because
you're alone.
You're not seeing anybody.

J.F. MUSIAL: It's like
a mental game.

SVEN QUANDT: The whole Dakar
is a mental game.

You must be mentally very
strong to survive.

STEPHANE PETERHANSEL: We start
with a chrono, with a timer.

And some time during all the
day, five hours for the stage,

for example, you see nobody,
no other car.

And you don't know exactly what
is your time, what is

your position on the
classification.

SVEN QUANDT: This is a very
tricky mental game to know

where you are, what
speed you do.

And you cannot do 100% all day,
because nobody can drive
six hours 100% full stop.
That's not possible.

So I'd say that's the much
bigger challenge compared to

most of the other races, where
you don't know where your
other competitors are.
So that's our small workshop.
J.F. MUSIAL: Small?

SVEN QUANDT: Small
in contrast.

It's too small, actually,
already.
At the moment, it's OK.

But on the Dakar preparation,
this here is full, full, full.

We park the cars in the middle,
even, because it's not
enough space.

At the moment, we are
considering building a new
place, basically next door.

So that's basically
the work bays.

We have got still some with
lifts, but most of the bays
are without lifts.

A lift has got an advantage
when you build a
car the first time.
It's nice.

But for training for the people,
you try to run them on

the stand like this, still some
cars because of space.

And when you do some cars
quickly, it's nicer
to do it like this.
That's, for example, Stephane's
car from this Dakar.

J.F. MUSIAL: This is
the one that won?

SVEN QUANDT: This is the car,
the real car, which won.

It looks quite nice, nearly
brand-new, because this is

what Stephane is doing
to his cars.

Because all the cars he raced,
I can tell you, are like new
when he raced them.

STEPHANE PETERHANSEL: You know
if you are too much aggressive

with a car, it's really easy
to break something.

I prefer to drive very smooth,
not too much aggressive.

I did 10 Dakars with
a motorcycle.

And I've never had
a big crash.

SVEN QUANDT: If you look
underneath, there's no tubes
bent, no nothing.

The car, we did some very little
marks on the front.

But the rest is 100% original,
no scratches, no nothing.
That's him.
J.F. MUSIAL: Less work.

STEPHANE PETERHANSEL:
I prefer to feel the
time to be full attack.

Sometimes I have not a good
feeling, so I prefer
to reduce the speed.

Or sometimes, I'm really
confident.

This time, it's really perfect
to be full attack, so just a
question of feeling.

SVEN QUANDT: The actual planning
for the Dakar from a

technical point of view starts
more than a year before.

Basically when we are finished
and send the cars out in late

November, we're already planning
for the following

Dakar, which is basically one
year and one month later.

The car itself has got--
basically, it's a Mini body, a
Mini Countryman body.

Underneath, you have
a tubular frame.

It's made to the specifications,
what we are

allowed to do from
the regulation.

The regulation on the Dakar
is quite tight.

You have a maximum wheelbase
of 2 meter 90,
which is not a lot.

And what limits us more is the
suspension stroke, which is
250 millimeters.

J.F. MUSIAL: That's
the travel?

SVEN QUANDT: That's the travel,
what you can have.

And that's about that much,
to give you an idea.

And you run through holes
like this, and you
must be still fast.

So we spend lots of time
and money on suspension
development.

These shock absorbers you've
got here I think is, at the

moment, probably the most
sophisticated you can get
around the world.

Us and WRC are basically
keeping up like this.

At the moment, I think they're
a bit higher, because our

company supplying the shock
absorbers is now-- we are the

lead, basically, company
where they're
developing shock absorbers.
[CAR ENGINE]

J.F. MUSIAL: This is really
the business end
of the whole operation.

This is where the copilot sits,
navigator, mechanic.

Well, in fact, they each can do
each other's job, but this

guy's actually the one that's
actually most active.

And behind the scenes, when you
talk to these guys, they

say, the guy in the right seat
is actually doing more than

the guy in the left seat,
because he's got to focus on
navigation.

He's got to focus on telemetry
coming off of the car, making

sure all the systems are working
properly, as well as

making sure that the driver
keeps his right foot down.
And they're redundant systems.

Now, you won't see the
GPS systems here.

Because that's actually issued
by the FIA two days before the

event starts, so there's no
unfair advantage in terms of
those GPS units ahead of time.

You do get the typical rally
trip computers, redundancy as

well, simple controls on the
right-hand side that the

driver can use, as well as
buttons on the floor, so they

can reset the trip computer with
their feet if they've got
the book in their hand.

It's got a sequential six-speed
transmission mounted

to the front, a diesel 3-liter
turbocharged motor.

It's a BMW motor, like
out of the X3.

The other thing to remember with
the GPS is that it's not

actually what they use
to navigate with.

The reason it's issued by the
FIA is because it is not

actually the primary source of
getting from point A to point

B. That's what you use the
trip computers for.

That's part of the challenge
of doing Dakar, doing Abu
Dhabi or Morocco.

The GPS units only actually
are activated when you're

within three kilometers
of your checkpoint.

So if you're outside of that
three-kilometer radius, you're

not actually seeing anything
on the GPS.
That's part of the challenge.

You have to get within the
three kilometers, and
then it turns on.

And that's one of the very cool
and interesting parts of

this sport, is that it's not
only about going fast, but

being consistent and getting
there in the correct manner,
in the correct way.

And yes, it is an off-road
vehicle.

And when you're off-road, you
can go as fast as you want.

But just like any other rally,
you are using public roads.

And that also means that
you have to abide by
public speed limits.

So they've actually got a very
interesting way of doing the
pit lane speed limiter.

So you could choose what
kilometer an hour you need to

be driving and just set
the car to do that.

And the driver just
stays flat.

So it's actually the co-driver
that's dictating how fast the
driver's going.

It's very interesting
and very cool stuff.

Like any rally car, you
need to bring supplies
with you on your trip.

Of course, there's the
essentials like water, some
food, tire, wrench.

But when you do cross-country
rallies, like Dakar, like Abu

Dhabi, like Morocco, you've
got to bring a lot more,
things that are unexpected.

So it's not only what you bring,
but where you hide
those supplies.

For example, keeping the
center of gravity low.

Right by the exhaust, you'll
actually find an axle.

And deep inside here, you'll
find air jacks.

You'll find other tools,
other supplies.

In here, you've got
safety road kits,
torque wrench, air gun.

And then as you come back here,
you're not just bringing
one tire with you.

You're actually bringing upwards
of three, so one here,

one here, and another one
that can fit here.

You're not always bringing
three, but
you can bring three.

All the tires are exactly the
same, so you can put any of
them on any side of the car.

Over here, of course, you've
got your first
aid kit, your water.

And then inside, every nook and
cranny is a place to hide
something that you may need.

Because you never know,
especially if you're 300, 400

K out in the middle of the
desert, and you're the only

one that can work on the
car, you have to bring
everything with you.

Or that could just cost you
a year of preparation and

hundreds of thousands
of dollars.

So you're trying to assure that
everything that could go
wrong, there's a plan for it--
Murphy's law.

And that's kind of the beauty
of this, especially in these
remote countries.

You can't just pick up
supplies anywhere
alongside the road.

You've got to bring them with
you, which is what makes these
cars so remarkable.
Yes, they're fast.
Yes, they're reliable.

But they're also the perfect
bug-out vehicle.

You can literally live out of
this vehicle, if you really
needed to, for days at a time.

And of course, the people behind
the wheel are not only

excellent drivers and co-drivers
and navigators, but
they're also mechanics.

They need to know how
to work on the cars.

And because there is no
communication directly to the

service area unless you have a
satellite phone, you really

have to have the ability
to think on your
feet and think fast.

STEPHANE PETERHANSEL: When I
stopped with the motorcycle, I

start now 13 years ago with a
car, on the tour the first

time with Jean-Paul Cottret,
my co-driver.
And we are again together.

So during 13 years, we did
all the racing together.
He's probably--

not probably-- is the best
co-driver in the world of
rally raid.

He never said to me, for
example, Stephane, you are too
fast, too slow.

He's really cool
inside the car.

But I think that maybe he's
the boss inside the car.
I don't like to do mechanics.

But my co-driver, his first
job was mechanics.
So he likes to do it.

So it's a good balance
with him.

J.F. MUSIAL: You give
him the water while
he changes the tire.
STEPHANE PETERHANSEL: Exactly.

I give him the tools, key number
12, key number 14.

But he manages everything
if we have a problem.

SVEN QUANDT: You have a
very high fuel tank,
very big fuel tank.

You talk about 400 liters on a
diesel car, and about 600 on a
petrol car.
This he had open already.

Because if you see, there's
three spare tires, which you
need during the day.

And sometimes you really
need them.

And you have the fuel tank
there below, which has a

capacity here of
not quite 400.

But that's enough for us,
because fuel consumption is
quite good on a car like this.

Minimum range is
800 kilometers.

Without this, you are not
allowed, basically, to start.
It's a prototype.

The body is a little bit bigger
than a real Countryman

because it is 4 centimeters
wider and 5% bigger in total

to have all the possibilities
to fit everything inside.

Still, there are some original
parts on the car.

Besides this one, obviously
lights and door handles, and

the glass even at the front,
the front window, is an

original glass from
a Countryman.

So we tried to use as much as
possible things from the
original car.

The people you have got
in the team, most of
them are very special.

It's a crowd of mechanics,
engineers, technicians who
really love the sport as well.

If they haven't got
the motivation,
it's very, very difficult.

Because without this, you
will not survive.

And I can tell you, I've got
big people, tall people,

really strong people starting
to cry after day two because
they couldn't take it.

So you have to find the people
who are very good skills, love

the job, are very focused
on details, as well.

Starting from the heart of the
car, which is the engine,
which is from BMW, a Mini.

Basically we used until last
year full prototypes.

So we were always two to three
years ahead of the normal
production engine.

So a lot of things went back to
the factory and have been

then introduced in
the standard.

J.F. MUSIAL: Is there an element
of, if you were coming

up and there was a car ahead of
you that started before you

that crashes, do
you guys help?

What's the etiquette in terms
of, if there's a car broken

down and they're OK,
do you keep going?
NANI ROMA: You stop, always.
J.F. MUSIAL: You always stop?
NANI ROMA: Always.

Yeah, this is part
of the game.

You start, and when you see
some accident and the
guys say OK, OK.
You start.

But normally, when I see
some crash, always I
stop, minimum to ask.
Is it OK or not OK?

And when you see something,
you stop, and you take up.

J.F. MUSIAL: 15 minutes down
the road from X-raid's
workshop is a quarry.

And like any other quarry,
this one is filled with

construction equipment and very
large boulders, boulders

you don't want to hit in a half
a million dollar truck.

Earlier in the day, Will Barber,
the guy responsible

for shooting all these "Driven"
episodes, came out to

the quarry and rode shotgun
to get some B-roll.

When I met up with him, he told
me the footage he got was

pretty much unusable because
of the ride.

But he also said one
other thing, and
this is a true story.

He said, quote, "I will never
have to go to space after what
I just
experienced." Thank you.

So tell me, this is your first
time on this, or no?
NANI ROMA: No.

The track yes, this time today,
but normally, sometimes

we test something in the car
here before we come to

Morocco, test a little bit the
car, but all last year also so
we could drive.

J.F. MUSIAL: Does this simulate
anything at Dakar?
NANI ROMA: Yeah.
Dakar is the same.
J.F. MUSIAL: Oh, OK.

NANI ROMA: The right side
is the difficult place.
J.F. MUSIAL: Thanks.
As we set off.

This is a difficult
place to be.
NANI ROMA: Really difficult.
[CAR ENGINE]

J.F. MUSIAL: We're going
60 miles an hour
over sand and dirt.

NANI ROMA: This is the
place, with the mud--
not easy, you know.

J.F. MUSIAL: I wouldn't
be able to do this.

How the hell are you supposed
to read notes?

NANI ROMA: Imagine who
writes the notes.

J.F. MUSIAL: I can't even look
at my watch on these skids.

How are you supposed
to read [BLEEP]?
Holy [BLEEP].
I have no control over--

NANI ROMA: Myself, only you have
some stupid guy to one

side to plot out,
but not more.

But then, the co-driver has
a little bit of power.

He has the capacity to
say, OK, slow down.

But he doesn't have control a
lot the car about nothing.

J.F. MUSIAL: You know, there's
a lot of throttle control.
NANI ROMA: Yeah.

You know, I brake with
my left foot.

And this is how I have
control of the car.
Whoa, look.
Whoa.

I throttle, throttle, and
I'm upright, you know?

J.F. MUSIAL: You're rotating
the car with
the brakes and throttle.
NANI ROMA: Yeah.

When I come like that, and I
brake to the right foot, I
brake and the car--
I don't have control.
Look at that.

J.F. MUSIAL: The car's
stepping out.

NANI ROMA: And the same thing,
but with the left foot.
Look.
J.F. MUSIAL: Got it.
NANI ROMA: Always like that.
I have a speed.

With this, I have the capacity
to whoa, whoa.

J.F. MUSIAL: You're also using
the compression of the car to
help slow down.

NANI ROMA: And they
either see--
turn, turn, and I turn.

You need to use all the
powers to help you.
I feel the grip, it's OK.

When I don't have the
grip, it's not OK.

J.F. MUSIAL: Whoa,
that was a tree.
[ENGINE REVVING]
J.F. MUSIAL: Holy [BLEEP].
NANI ROMA: [LAUGHS]

J.F. MUSIAL: Doing 110
K over a bump.

NANI ROMA: The machine has
100 kilometers here.
This is hard.
Now it's 3, 4, 5 kilometers.

But when you start at a stage
like 400 kilometers, 800

kilometers, it's
different here.
J.F. MUSIAL: Oh, boy.
Now we're doing donuts?
Awesome, man.

I've been in a lot of fast cars
in my life, but that was
pretty fun.

That was actually the most fun
I've had in a vehicle.
[CAR ENGINE]

title: 110mph Over Sand Dunes - Inside X-raid and MINI ALL4 Racing - /DRIVEN

comments.text:
This week we're highlighting some of our favorite auto videos on +YouTube! 
We're big fans of DRIVE's YT channel so to start you out we're taking you 
off of the race track and into the realm X-raid's amazing cross-country 
rally team. 110mph in a mini cooper over sand dunes? No problem!﻿
comments.author: casie rice

comments.text: Amazing and great!﻿
comments.author: Justin Landis

comments.text:
A never before seen look of X-raid Team, the Dakar winning international 
Cross-Country Rally Team. A shop tour of their facility outside of 
Frankfurt Germany, watch how the team builds and tests their fleet of MINI 
ALL4 Racing
#xraid #Dakar2015 #DakarRally #MiniAll4Racing  ﻿
comments.author: Dakar Rally Raid - Endurance Rally Racing

comments.text: Fantastico! ﻿
comments.author: ThePatroldoc

comments.text: Whats the song at 8 mins in? sounds a bit like Seba/Klute﻿
comments.author: Robert Iddon

comments.text:
What a stupid statement, being tall and strong has absolutely nothing to do 
with emotional integrity, only an equally stupid person would see reason in 
that. It is almost insulting that he would use an example as stupid as that 
to describe how gruelling the dakar is...﻿
comments.author: BlueFatalis

comments.text:
250mm is 10" which isn't all that bad. I'm guessing thats like an inherent 
safety feature, keeping the driving from pushing to hard for days in a row. 
compared to something like trophy trucks with feet of travel nearly flying 
across similar terrain﻿
comments.author: Swansen03

comments.text:
110mph isn't bad but, I know a certain American who is a little quicker. 
Good luck Mini's.........LOL﻿
comments.author: Jerod Slaybaugh

comments.text: minis dind had luck, 4 cars in top 5. where were does 110+mph americans?
comments.author: Luis Freitas

comments.text:
That Hummer only works in Baja, where there are no suspension travel 
restriction. for the Dakar nowadays you need a WRC car with higher 
suspension and storage. But I like Gordon's mentality - Pedal to the metal!
comments.author: bongada

comments.text:
+bongada Ouch...ok maybe next year. Soon we will beat the Factory teams. 
Cheers
comments.author: Jerod Slaybaugh

comments.text: well, how about that american?
comments.author: bongada

comments.text:
As someone who loves her MINI with all her heart, this is incredible and 
makes me insanely happy <3﻿
comments.author: MaryFrancis Benning

comments.text:
How do you get involved with this kind of reporting?  Do you call them up 
and ask to sit in their car?  Or do they give you a bunch of footage and 
you just report it?﻿
comments.author: Robert Haney

comments.text:
Vídeo da equipe Monster Energy X-Raid, campeã do Dakar 2012/2013, da qual a 
KS Tools é fornecedora exclusiva de ferramentas.﻿
comments.author: KS Tools Ferramentas de Segurança

comments.text: only 110 km/h gay it sad mph

comments.text: awesome episode! thank you Drive! (again)
comments.author: wiskunst

comments.text: If I had a mini that looked like that I'd drive it.
comments.author: THEMULTIMCMUFFINS

comments.text:
110mph Over Sand Dunes - Inside X-raid and MINI ALL4 Racing - /DRIVEN

MINI Cooper S ALL4 jumping sand dunes at 110mph.  

Pretty crazy!

#MINI   #ALL4   ﻿
comments.author: MINI of Kennesaw Parts

comments.text:
This week we're highlighting some of our favorite auto videos on +YouTube! 
We're big fans of DRIVE's YT channel so to start you out we're taking you 
off of the race track and into the realm X-raid's amazing cross-country 
rally team. 110mph in a mini cooper over sand dunes? No problem!﻿

comments.text: MURICA
comments.author: Alexander Est

comments.text:
You're dumb as shit... Robby Gordon practically runs a Trophy Truck in the 
2WD class, and he MOPS the fuck out of the Minis. He just doesn't have the 
big financial support that Peterhansel has. Oh and plenty of Americans run 
the Dakar.
comments.author: theKOchannel

comments.text: I was actually joking, you see.
comments.author: frozenskipper

comments.text:
have you ever seen dakar? peterhansel has the record for both motorcycle 
and car
comments.author: Lars-Åke Chesburg

comments.text: No one is in the same league as Loeb.
comments.author: frozenskipper

comments.text: sounds like a rally car
comments.author: Oussama Erraji

comments.text:

comments.text: they wouldn't last, the trucks or the Americans.
comments.author: DirtMcGirt BBJ

comments.text:
I could watch the in car footage all day. Or at least until I got sick and 
then I'd resume watching..
comments.author: Monty Totten

comments.text:

comments.author: Raahul Chandar

comments.text: You Forget to Mansion Pharaons Rally that's a Fatal Mistake
comments.author: HossaM|7oss El Leel|

comments.text: name of the song at 8:15 please :)
comments.author: Umer Khawar

comments.text: He sayd that they get it from their suplier..
comments.author: Mera Narcis-Alexandru

comments.text:
the B-footage at the end is incredible - anyone who has gone fast on dirt 
can look at that and see how fast and rough that ride is. Good piece guys!
comments.author: DownWith theFourEleven

comments.text:
Unfair and stupid Real men don't need a big engine or huge tires or like 
30" of suspension travel to go fast. Also, Americans don't know how to 
navigate, they'd get lost in no time, just like Robby Gordon does ;-)
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text: Yeah they're huge :/ and ugly...
comments.author: Jamiewaldie1992

comments.text:
the guy @ 7:40 is implying that they make the shocks, but the shocks are 
from Reiger, it's a independent dutch company.. so they are really not 
theirs..
comments.author: Jérôme B

comments.text:
Wish they would let full blown Trophy trucks with no restrictions. run the 
Dakar
comments.author: Zackery Kingman

comments.text:
its kind of annoying that the presenter always says "got it" all the time 
(I am not hating i like the content, i am just giving constructive 
criticism)
comments.author: Triplescout

comments.text:
i'm not saying to race a trophy truck in dakar, just to take a ride in one.

so you are telling me that the design on the rear of the car at 11:44 is

comments.author: VolvoGuy97

comments.text:
The cost of the events vary A LOT. Most European countries have National 
cross-country championships with 1-day and 2-day races. If you want to know 
more about car preparation, check the FIA cross-country rally rulebook for 
the T2 class (it's a bit like the Gr.N from rallying)
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
2WD cars are allowed to have a much longer suspension travel. It's like a 
balance: with AWD you get much better traction but with 2WD you can have 
better suspension and auto-inflatable tires
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
The driver of the ride-along is Spaniard Joan "Nani" Roma. He's from the 
countryside and he has raced a ton of French-organized raids during his 
career. Also, he used to have a French co-driver. I guess that makes for a 
funny English accent The other driver is Stephane Peterhansel AKA "Monseiur 
Dakar". He is French
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
Not at all, the sponsors are much different. Also, Peterhansel and Roma can 
drive without needing 8 takes per corner, not like that asshole ;-)
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
The 2 main drivers of X-raid are French Stephane Peterhansel (5-time Dakar 
rally winner in the bike class and like 3-4 more times with cars) and 
Spaniard Joan "Nani" Roma (once Dakar rally winner in the bike class). 
"Nani" is the driver when JF is sitting next to him
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text: Lying is lying and you're supposed to be JOURNALISTS
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
Have you seen the Mini Countryman?? It's quite big, not Mini-ish at all. 
This car is just 5% bigger overall than a stock Mini Countryman
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
Isn't that "too secret"?? I mean, it's almost like visiting a F1 factory. I 
hope they let you give some actual insight and not some tourist-like info 
:-)
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
No no, Joan "Nani" Roma said he used the movement of the car (the inertia) 
to help the engine to make turns faster and more agile
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
You're not allowed to do that within FIA cross-country rallies. Also, the 
Dakar rally has only been won 2 times with a 2WD buggy in recent times 
(Jean-Lois Schlesser twice with his self-built machines)
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
All X-raid cars have all those spare parts. You never know what will 
happen. If you get seriously damaged, the assistance truck may need up to 
3h to get to you. You cannot loose that much time so you need to be able to 
repair it by yourself. Also, these cross-country raids are considered 
"adventure races" so you MUST have basic supplies to survive around 48h 
easily on your own
comments.author: Diego Ruiz

comments.text:
*X-Raid MINI on DRIVE*

JF visits the Frankfurt race shop of X-Raid, the  rally team that preps and 
fields race "trucks" in international cross-country rallying events, 
including Dakar. The X-Raid MINI has been the teams most successful vehicle 
to date and is a big part of Stéphane Peterhansel's 2012 and 2013 Dakar 
wins.﻿
comments.author: Evan Ezewski

comments.author: TheSheepherd

comments.text:
FIA mandates a minimum driving range of 800 km on the cars, to build in 
some margin of error. This Mini's fuel cell is "not quite" 400 L, which is 
at least good for that much, if not more. Considering these things carry 
enough spare parts to just about build a second car, I don't expect this is 
some WRC featherweight (the Dakar Car class is anything up to 3500 kg). 
Between that and the conditions they drive in, that sounds like decent fuel 
consumption to me.
comments.author: DMStraylight

comments.text: Rally or die!
